claim: Flublok contains 3x the hemagglutinin (HA) antigen content of standard-dose flu vaccines, which has been linked to greater immunogenicity vs standard-dose flu vaccines.
explanation: Composite of eight graphs showing microneutralization (MN) or hemagglutination inhibition (HI) antibody titers (log2 scale) against influenza strains A(H3N2), A(H1N1)pdm09, B/Victoria, and B/Yamagata at Day 0, 1 month, and 6 months post-vaccination. Four vaccine groups are plotted: egg-based IIV4 (Fluzone), another egg-based IIV4 (Fluarix), cell-based IIV4 (ccIIV4), and recombinant HA vaccine (RIV4). Individual titers are shown as gray dots; geometric mean titers with 95% CIs are shown, with horizontal bars and p-values indicating significant differences between groups. Evidence: RIV4 (recombinant HA vaccine) induced higher MN or HI titers at 1 and 6 months compared to the three standard-dose IIV4 vaccines, as indicated by statistically significant p values. The figure does not support the claim that Flublok contains 3× the HA antigen content, because it provides only immunogenicity comparisons without any data on antigen content or the 3× HA dose specification, although it does show greater immunogenicity for RIV4 versus standard-dose vaccines. Note: Image does not include any quantitative information on HA antigen amounts or dosing; immunogenicity data alone are shown; some p-values and axis labels are small and may be hard to read clearly.
